Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of measurement and testing equipment for distributed wireless communications and localization systems and propagation channels

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches:
The objective of this research is the development of measurement instrumentation that will enable (i) measurement of distributed wireless propagation channels with ultra-wide bandwidth and (ii) design, measurement and validation of distributed wireless systems for communications, localization, and radar. The instrumentation is thus intended to explore both the fundamental principles of distributed wireless propagation channels and systems, as well as to enable the development and testing of practical distributed wireless systems that go far beyond current systems. The approach is based on a combination of state-of-the array channel sounding with electro-optical signal conversion. By converting wideband microwave signals to optical signals, which are transmitted via optical fibers, widely separated antennas can be operated by a single high-precision signal source/receiver in a synchronized manner.

Intellectual Merit:
Firstly, the development activity will push the frontiers of electro-optical modulation. Secondly, the instrument enables many measurements that will for the first time answer some of the fundamental questions related to wireless propagation in distributed systems, such as the correlation of shadowing, delay spread, and angular spread at widely separated transmitters/receivers. Further intellectual merit is obtained from the use of these measurement results to stimulate and test novel theoretical ideas.

Broader impact:
Measurements with the developed instrumentation will help to enable novel applications of distributed wireless systems (many of which are ?Grand Challenges? defined by the National Academy), such as wireless health and remote monitoring of vital signs, distributed localization for emergency responders, high-efficiency video distribution systems, and many more.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Two of the major trends of our information society are ever-increasing demand for speed and reliability of communications, and the interplay between communications and localization. Both of these trends require the use of larger bandwidths – for communications, because larger bandwidth means faster connectivity, as well as better resilience against fading and interference; for localization because time-of-arrival based localization becomes more and more precise as the bandwidth increases. Another important trend is the use of distributed infrastructure, again in order to achieve better reliability as well as a means to reduce energy consumption and thus make wireless systems more “green”.

 

A prerequisite for the design of any wireless system is to understand the propagation channel in which it operates – in other words, how does the signal get from point A to point B? There are many complicated effects involved, from multipath propagation to dispersion, and measurements (also known as “channel sounding”) are critically important to have such proper understanding. While channel measurements for “normal” cellular and WiFi systems have been done for a long time, the impact of wider bandwidth and distributed systems has not been considered up to now.

 

To close this gap, in this project, we developed a measurement instrumentation that will enable measurements of distributed wireless propagation channels with ultrawide bandwidth. It furthermore enables design, measurement and validation of distributed wireless systems for communications, localization, and radar. The key components of this system are cutting-edge (commercial) waveform generators and digitizers, which we combined with a number of additional components into a complete instrumentation that can measure with bandwidths of up to 10 GHz (much larger than currently used in most systems, and thus future-proof). In contrast to many other existing systems, it can measure dynamic effects, and – due to the capability of streaming larger amount of data to mass storage – can measure over long periods of time. The ability to measure distributed setups with just one of the (complicated and expensive) transmitters and digitizers is achieved by sending radio signals over fiber-optical links. All of the hardware is made more useful by a number of signal processing innovations we have developed during the course of this project, as well as careful calibration.

 

Sample results we have achieved up to now are measurements of three-dimensional channel characteristics with large bandwidths and localization of passive targets in a shadowed environment with severe multipath. In future years, we will use the instrumentation for large-scale measurement campaigns and evaluate the results both at USC and in collaboration with other US universities.
